1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">In general i18n has to be attached to the response object to let it's public api get accessible in your templates and methods. As of <strong>0.4.0</strong> i18n tries to do so internally via <code>i18n.init</code>, as if you were doing it in <code>app.configure</code> on your own:</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-js notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="app.use(function (req, res, next) {  // express helper for natively supported engines  res.locals.__ = res.__ = function () {    return i18n.__.apply(req, arguments)  }  // [...]  next()})"><pre><span class="pl-s1">app</span><span class="pl-kos">.</span><span class="pl-en">use</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-k">function</span> <span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-s1">req</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-s1">res</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-s1">next</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span> <span class="pl-kos">{</span>  <span class="pl-c">// express helper for natively supported engines</span>  <span class="pl-s1">res</span><span class="pl-kos">.</span><span class="pl-c1">locals</span><span class="pl-kos">.</span><span class="pl-c1">__</span> <span class="pl-c1">=</span> <span class="pl-s1">res</span><span class="pl-kos">.</span><span class="pl-en">__</span> <span class="pl-c1">=</span> <span class="pl-k">function</span> <span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span> <span class="pl-kos">{</span>    <span class="pl-k">return</span> <span class="pl-s1">i18n</span><span class="pl-kos">.</span><span class="pl-c1">__</span><span class="pl-kos">.</span><span class="pl-en">apply</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-s1">req</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-smi">arguments</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span>  <span class="pl-kos">}</span>  <span class="pl-c">// [...]</span>  <span class="pl-s1">next</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span><span class="pl-kos">}</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span></pre></div><p dir="auto">Different engines need different implementations, so yours might miss or not work with the current default helpers. This one showing an example for mustache in express:</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-js notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="// register helper as a locals function wrapped as mustache expectsapp.use(function (req, res, next) {  // mustache helper  res.locals.__ = function () {    return function (text, render) {      return i18n.__.apply(req, arguments)    }  }  // [...]  next()})"><pre><span class="pl-c">// register helper as a locals function wrapped as mustache expects</span><span class="pl-s1">app</span><span class="pl-kos">.</span><span class="pl-en">use</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-k">function</span> <span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-s1">req</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-s1">res</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-s1">next</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span> <span class="pl-kos">{</span>  <span class="pl-c">// mustache helper</span>  <span class="pl-s1">res</span><span class="pl-kos">.</span><span class="pl-c1">locals</span><span class="pl-kos">.</span><span class="pl-en">__</span> <span class="pl-c1">=</span> <span class="pl-k">function</span> <span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span> <span class="pl-kos">{</span>    <span class="pl-k">return</span> <span class="pl-k">function</span> <span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-s1">text</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-s1">render</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span> <span class="pl-kos">{</span>      <span class="pl-k">return</span> <span class="pl-s1">i18n</span><span class="pl-kos">.</span><span class="pl-c1">__</span><span class="pl-kos">.</span><span class="pl-en">apply</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-s1">req</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-smi">arguments</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span>    <span class="pl-kos">}</span>  <span class="pl-kos">}</span>  <span class="pl-c">// [...]</span>  <span class="pl-s1">next</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span><span class="pl-kos">}</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span></pre></div><p dir="auto">You could still setup your own implementation. Please refer to Examples below, post an issue or contribute your setup.</p><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h2 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Output formats</h2><a id="user-content-output-formats" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: Output formats" href="#output-formats"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">As inspired by gettext there is currently support for sprintf-style expressions. You can also use mustache syntax for named parameters.</p><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">sprintf support</h3><a id="user-content-sprintf-support" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: sprintf support" href="#sprintf-support"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><div class="highlight highlight-source-js notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="var greeting = __('Hello %s, how are you today?', 'Marcus')"><pre><span class="pl-k">var</span> <span class="pl-s1">greeting</span> <span class="pl-c1">=</span> <span class="pl-c1">__</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-s">'Hello %s, how are you today?'</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-s">'Marcus'</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span></pre></div><p dir="auto">this puts <em>Hello Marcus, how are you today?</em>. You might add endless arguments and even nest it.</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-js notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="var greeting = __('Hello %s, how are you today? How was your %s.', 'Marcus', __('weekend'))"><pre><span class="pl-k">var</span> <span class="pl-s1">greeting</span> <span class="pl-c1">=</span> <span class="pl-c1">__</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-s">'Hello %s, how are you today? How was your %s.'</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-s">'Marcus'</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-c1">__</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-s">'weekend'</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span></pre></div><p dir="auto">which puts <em>Hello Marcus, how are you today? How was your weekend.</em></p><p dir="auto">You might need to have repeated references to the same argument, which can be done with sprintf.</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-js notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="var example = __('%1$s, %1$s, %1$s', 'repeat')"><pre><span class="pl-k">var</span> <span class="pl-s1">example</span> <span class="pl-c1">=</span> <span class="pl-c1">__</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-s">'%1$s, %1$s, %1$s'</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-s">'repeat'</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span></pre></div><p dir="auto">which puts</p><div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="repeat, repeat, repeat"><pre class="notranslate"><code>repeat, repeat, repeat</code></pre></div><p dir="auto">In some cases the argument order will need to be switched for different locales.  The arguments can be strings, floats, numbers, etc.</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-js notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="var example = __('%2$d then %1$s then %3$.2f', 'First', 2, 333.333)"><pre><span class="pl-k">var</span> <span class="pl-s1">example</span> <span class="pl-c1">=</span> <span class="pl-c1">__</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-s">'%2$d then %1$s then %3$.2f'</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-s">'First'</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-c1">2</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-c1">333.333</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span></pre></div><p dir="auto">which puts</p><div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="2 then First then 333.33"><pre class="notranslate"><code>2 then First then 333.33</code></pre></div><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">mustache support</h3><a id="user-content-mustache-support" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: mustache support" href="#mustache-support"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">You may also use <a href="http://mustache.github.io/" rel="nofollow">mustache</a> syntax for your message strings. To pass named parameters to your message, just provide an object as the last parameter. You can still pass unnamed parameters by adding additional arguments.</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-js notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="var greeting = __('Hello {{name}}, how are you today?', { name: 'Marcus' })"><pre><span class="pl-k">var</span> <span class="pl-s1">greeting</span> <span class="pl-c1">=</span> <span class="pl-c1">__</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-s">'Hello {{name}}, how are you today?'</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-kos">{</span> <span class="pl-c1">name</span>: <span class="pl-s">'Marcus'</span> <span class="pl-kos">}</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span></pre></div><p dir="auto">this puts <em>Hello Marcus, how are you today?</em>. You might also combine it with sprintf arguments...</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-js notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="var greeting = __('Hello {{name}}, how was your %s.', __('weekend'), { name: 'Marcus' })"><pre><span class="pl-k">var</span> <span class="pl-s1">greeting</span> <span class="pl-c1">=</span> <span class="pl-c1">__</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-s">'Hello {{name}}, how was your %s.'</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-c1">__</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-s">'weekend'</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-kos">{</span> <span class="pl-c1">name</span>: <span class="pl-s">'Marcus'</span> <span class="pl-kos">}</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span></pre></div><p dir="auto">and even nest it...</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-js notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="var greeting = __( __('Hello {{name}}, how was your %s?', { name: 'Marcus' }), __('weekend') )"><pre><span class="pl-k">var</span> <span class="pl-s1">greeting</span> <span class="pl-c1">=</span> <span class="pl-c1">__</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span> <span class="pl-c1">__</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-s">'Hello {{name}}, how was your %s?'</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-kos">{</span> <span class="pl-c1">name</span>: <span class="pl-s">'Marcus'</span> <span class="pl-kos">}</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-c1">__</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-s">'weekend'</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span> <span class="pl-kos">)</span></pre></div><p dir="auto">which both put <em>Hello Marcus, how was your weekend.</em></p><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h4 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">how about markup?</h4><a id="user-content-how-about-markup" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: how about markup?" href="#how-about-markup"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">Including markup in translation and/or variables is considered to be bad practice, as it leads to side effects (translators need to understand it, might break it, inject malformed markup or worse). But well, mustache supports unescaped markup out-of-the-box (<em>Quote from <a href="https://mustache.github.io/mustache.5.html" rel="nofollow">https://mustache.github.io/mustache.5.html</a></em>):</p><blockquote><p dir="auto">All variables are HTML escaped by default. If you want to return unescaped HTML, use the triple mustache: {{{name}}}.</p></blockquote><p dir="auto">So this will work</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-js notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="var greeting = __('Hello {{{name}}}, how are you today?', { name: '<u>Marcus</u>' })"><pre><span class="pl-k">var</span> <span class="pl-s1">greeting</span> <span class="pl-c1">=</span> <span class="pl-c1">__</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-s">'Hello {{{name}}}, how are you today?'</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-kos">{</span> <span class="pl-c1">name</span>: <span class="pl-s">'<u>Marcus</u>'</span> <span class="pl-kos">}</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span></pre></div><p dir="auto">as expected:</p><div class="highlight highlight-text-html-basic notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="Hello <u>Marcus</u>, how are you today"><pre>Hello <span class="pl-kos"><</span><span class="pl-ent">u</span><span class="pl-kos">></span>Marcus<span class="pl-kos"></</span><span class="pl-ent">u</span><span class="pl-kos">></span>, how are you today</pre></div><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">basic plural support</h3><a id="user-content-basic-plural-support" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: basic plural support" href="#basic-plural-support"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">two different plural forms are supported as response to <code>count</code>:</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-js notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="var singular = __n('%s cat', '%s cats', 1)var plural = __n('%s cat', '%s cats', 3)"><pre><span class="pl-k">var</span> <span class="pl-s1">singular</span> <span class="pl-c1">=</span> <span class="pl-en">__n</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-s">'%s cat'</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-s">'%s cats'</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-c1">1</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span><span class="pl-k">var</span> <span class="pl-s1">plural</span> <span class="pl-c1">=</span> <span class="pl-en">__n</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-s">'%s cat'</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-s">'%s cats'</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-c1">3</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span></pre></div><p dir="auto">this puts <strong>1 cat</strong> or <strong>3 cats</strong>and again these could get nested:</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-js notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="var singular = __n('There is one monkey in the %%s', 'There are %d monkeys in the %%s', 1, 'tree')var plural = __n('There is one monkey in the %%s', 'There are %d monkeys in the %%s', 3, 'tree')"><pre><span class="pl-k">var</span> <span class="pl-s1">singular</span> <span class="pl-c1">=</span> <span class="pl-en">__n</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-s">'There is one monkey in the %%s'</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-s">'There are %d monkeys in the %%s'</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-c1">1</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-s">'tree'</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span><span class="pl-k">var</span> <span class="pl-s1">plural</span> <span class="pl-c1">=</span> <span class="pl-en">__n</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-s">'There is one monkey in the %%s'</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-s">'There are %d monkeys in the %%s'</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-c1">3</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-s">'tree'</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span></pre></div><p dir="auto">putting <em>There is one monkey in the tree</em> or <em>There are 3 monkeys in the tree</em>. Passing all 3 parameters would write a <code>one</code> and <code>other</code> to your json. For reading you might just use 2 parameters, too:</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-js notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="__n('%s cat', 1) // --> 1 Katze__n('%s cat', 3) // --> 3 Katzen"><pre><span class="pl-en">__n</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-s">'%s cat'</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-c1">1</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span> <span class="pl-c">// --> 1 Katze</span><span class="pl-en">__n</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-s">'%s cat'</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-c1">3</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span> <span class="pl-c">// --> 3 Katzen</span></pre></div><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">ranged interval support</h3><a id="user-content-ranged-interval-support" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: ranged interval support" href="#ranged-interval-support"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">use mathematical intervals to declare any own plural rules based on <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interval_(mathematics)#Notations_for_intervals" rel="nofollow">ISO 31-11</a> notation. Let's assume the following json snippet:</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-json notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=""dogs": {    "one": "one dog",    "other": "[0] no dog|[2,5] some dogs|[6,11] many dogs|[12,36] dozens of dogs|a horde of %s dogs|[100,] too many dogs"}"><pre><span class="pl-ent">"dogs"</span>: {    <span class="pl-ent">"one"</span>: <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>one dog<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>,    <span class="pl-ent">"other"</span>: <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>[0] no dog|[2,5] some dogs|[6,11] many dogs|[12,36] dozens of dogs|a horde of %s dogs|[100,] too many dogs<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>}</pre></div><p dir="auto">this will result in</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-js notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="__n('dogs', 0) // --> no dog__n('dogs', 1) // --> one dog__n('dogs', 2) // --> some dogs__n('dogs', 10) // --> many dogs__n('dogs', 25) // --> dozens of dogs__n('dogs', 42) // --> a horde of 42 dogs__n('dogs', 199) // --> too many dogs"><pre><span class="pl-en">__n</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-s">'dogs'</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-c1">0</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span> <span class="pl-c">// --> no dog</span><span class="pl-en">__n</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-s">'dogs'</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-c1">1</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span> <span class="pl-c">// --> one dog</span><span class="pl-en">__n</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-s">'dogs'</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-c1">2</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span> <span class="pl-c">// --> some dogs</span><span class="pl-en">__n</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-s">'dogs'</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-c1">10</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span> <span class="pl-c">// --> many dogs</span><span class="pl-en">__n</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-s">'dogs'</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-c1">25</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span> <span class="pl-c">// --> dozens of dogs</span><span class="pl-en">__n</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-s">'dogs'</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-c1">42</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span> <span class="pl-c">// --> a horde of 42 dogs</span><span class="pl-en">__n</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-s">'dogs'</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-c1">199</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span> <span class="pl-c">// --> too many dogs</span></pre></div><p dir="auto">The rules are parsed in sequenced order, so the first match will skip any extra rules. Example:</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-json notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="{    "dogs":"[0]no dog|[1]one dog|[,10[ less than ten dogs|[,20[ less than 20 dogs|too many dogs"}"><pre>{    <span class="pl-ent">"dogs"</span>:<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>[0]no dog|[1]one dog|[,10[ less than ten dogs|[,20[ less than 20 dogs|too many dogs<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>}</pre></div><p dir="auto">results in</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-js notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="// interval matched by number__n('dogs', 0) // --> no dog__n('dogs', 1) // --> one dog__n('dogs', 2) // --> less than ten dogs__n('dogs', 9) // --> less than ten dogs__n('dogs', 10) // --> less than 20 dogs__n('dogs', 19) // --> less than 20 dogs__n('dogs', 20) // --> too many dogs__n('dogs', 199) // --> too many dogs// no interval returned, but found a catchall__('dogs') // --> too many dogs"><pre><span class="pl-c">// interval matched by number</span><span class="pl-en">__n</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-s">'dogs'</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-c1">0</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span> <span class="pl-c">// --> no dog</span><span class="pl-en">__n</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-s">'dogs'</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-c1">1</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span> <span class="pl-c">// --> one dog</span><span class="pl-en">__n</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-s">'dogs'</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-c1">2</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span> <span class="pl-c">// --> less than ten dogs</span><span class="pl-en">__n</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-s">'dogs'</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-c1">9</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span> <span class="pl-c">// --> less than ten dogs</span><span class="pl-en">__n</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-s">'dogs'</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-c1">10</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span> <span class="pl-c">// --> less than 20 dogs</span><span class="pl-en">__n</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-s">'dogs'</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-c1">19</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span> <span class="pl-c">// --> less than 20 dogs</span><span class="pl-en">__n</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-s">'dogs'</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-c1">20</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span> <span class="pl-c">// --> too many dogs</span><span class="pl-en">__n</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-s">'dogs'</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-c1">199</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span> <span class="pl-c">// --> too many dogs</span><span class="pl-c">// no interval returned, but found a catchall</span><span class="pl-c1">__</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-s">'dogs'</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span> <span class="pl-c">// --> too many dogs</span></pre></div><p dir="auto">See <a href="https://github.com/mashpie/i18n-node/blob/master/locales/en.json">en.json example</a> inside <code>/locales</code> for some inspiration on use cases. Each phrase might get decorated further with mustache and sprintf expressions:</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-json notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="{    "example":"[0] %s is zero rule for {{me}}|[2,5] %s is between two and five for {{me}}|and a catchall rule for {{me}} to get my number %s"}"><pre>{    <span class="pl-ent">"example"</span>:<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>[0] %s is zero rule for {{me}}|[2,5] %s is between two and five for {{me}}|and a catchall rule for {{me}} to get my number %s<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>}</pre></div><p dir="auto">will put (as taken from tests):</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-js notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="// will always use a found catchall__('example', {me: 'marcus'}) // --> and a catchall rule for marcus to get my number %s__('example', ['one'], {me: 'marcus'}) // --> and a catchall rule for marcus to get my number one// will search a matching interval or fallback to catchall__n('example', 1, {me: 'marcus'}) // --> and a catchall rule for marcus to get my number 1__n('example', 2, {me: 'marcus'}) // --> 2 is between two and five for marcus__n('example', 5, {me: 'marcus'}) // --> 5 is between two and five for marcus__n('example', 3, {me: 'marcus'}) // --> 3 is between two and five for marcus__n('example', 6, {me: 'marcus'}) // --> and a catchall rule for marcus to get my number 6"><pre><span class="pl-c">// will always use a found catchall</span><span class="pl-c1">__</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-s">'example'</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-kos">{</span><span class="pl-c1">me</span>: <span class="pl-s">'marcus'</span><span class="pl-kos">}</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span> <span class="pl-c">// --> and a catchall rule for marcus to get my number %s</span><span class="pl-c1">__</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-s">'example'</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-kos">[</span><span class="pl-s">'one'</span><span class="pl-kos">]</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-kos">{</span><span class="pl-c1">me</span>: <span class="pl-s">'marcus'</span><span class="pl-kos">}</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span> <span class="pl-c">// --> and a catchall rule for marcus to get my number one</span><span class="pl-c">// will search a matching interval or fallback to catchall</span><span class="pl-en">__n</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-s">'example'</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-c1">1</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-kos">{</span><span class="pl-c1">me</span>: <span class="pl-s">'marcus'</span><span class="pl-kos">}</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span> <span class="pl-c">// --> and a catchall rule for marcus to get my number 1</span><span class="pl-en">__n</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-s">'example'</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-c1">2</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-kos">{</span><span class="pl-c1">me</span>: <span class="pl-s">'marcus'</span><span class="pl-kos">}</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span> <span class="pl-c">// --> 2 is between two and five for marcus</span><span class="pl-en">__n</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-s">'example'</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-c1">5</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-kos">{</span><span class="pl-c1">me</span>: <span class="pl-s">'marcus'</span><span class="pl-kos">}</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span> <span class="pl-c">// --> 5 is between two and five for marcus</span><span class="pl-en">__n</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-s">'example'</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-c1">3</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-kos">{</span><span class="pl-c1">me</span>: <span class="pl-s">'marcus'</span><span class="pl-kos">}</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span> <span class="pl-c">// --> 3 is between two and five for marcus</span><span class="pl-en">__n</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-s">'example'</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-c1">6</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-kos">{</span><span class="pl-c1">me</span>: <span class="pl-s">'marcus'</span><span class="pl-kos">}</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span> <span class="pl-c">// --> and a catchall rule for marcus to get my number 6</span></pre></div><blockquote><p dir="auto"><strong>Notice</strong>: the "example" object in your json doesn't use any "one", "other" subnodes although you <em>could</em> use and even combine them. Currently "one" referres to the value of exactly 1 while "other" referres to every other value (think of 0, -10, null, false)</p></blockquote><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">variable support</h3><a id="user-content-variable-support" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: variable support" href="#variable-support"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">you might even use dynamic variables as they get interpreted on the fly. Better make sure no user input finds it's way to that point as they all get added to the <code>en.js</code> file if not yet existing.</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-js notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="var greetings = ['Hi', 'Hello', 'Howdy']for (var i = 0; i < greetings.length; i++) {  console.log(__(greetings[i]))}"><pre><span class="pl-k">var</span> <span class="pl-s1">greetings</span> <span class="pl-c1">=</span> <span class="pl-kos">[</span><span class="pl-s">'Hi'</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-s">'Hello'</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-s">'Howdy'</span><span class="pl-kos">]</span><span class="pl-k">for</span> <span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-k">var</span> <span class="pl-s1">i</span> <span class="pl-c1">=</span> <span class="pl-c1">0</span><span class="pl-kos">;</span> <span class="pl-s1">i</span> <span class="pl-c1"><</span> <span class="pl-s1">greetings</span><span class="pl-kos">.</span><span class="pl-c1">length</span><span class="pl-kos">;</span> <span class="pl-s1">i</span><span class="pl-c1">++</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span> <span class="pl-kos">{</span>  <span class="pl-smi">console</span><span class="pl-kos">.</span><span class="pl-en">log</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-c1">__</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-s1">greetings</span><span class="pl-kos">[</span><span class="pl-s1">i</span><span class="pl-kos">]</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span><span class="pl-kos">}</span></pre></div><p dir="auto">which puts</p><div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="HiHelloHowdy"><pre class="notranslate"><code>HiHelloHowdy</code></pre></div><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h2 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Object notation</h2><a id="user-content-object-notation" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: Object notation" href="#object-notation"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">In addition to the traditional, linear translation lists, i18n also supports hierarchical translation catalogs.</p><p dir="auto">To enable this feature, be sure to set <code>objectNotation</code> to <code>true</code> in your <code>configure()</code> call. <strong>Note</strong>: If you can't or don't want to use <code>.</code> as a delimiter, set <code>objectNotation</code> to any other delimiter you like.</p><p dir="auto">Instead of calling <code>__("Hello")</code> you might call <code>__("greeting.formal")</code> to retrieve a formal greeting from a translation document like this one:</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-json notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="{  "greeting": {    "formal": "Hello",    "informal": "Hi",    "placeholder": {      "formal": "Hello %s",      "informal": "Hi %s"    }  }}"><pre>{  <span class="pl-ent">"greeting"</span>: {    <span class="pl-ent">"formal"</span>: <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>Hello<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>,    <span class="pl-ent">"informal"</span>: <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>Hi<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>,    <span class="pl-ent">"placeholder"</span>: {      <span class="pl-ent">"formal"</span>: <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>Hello %s<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>,      <span class="pl-ent">"informal"</span>: <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>Hi %s<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>    }  }}</pre></div><p dir="auto">In the document, the translation terms, which include placeholders, are nested inside the "greeting" translation. They can be accessed and used in the same way, like so <code>__('greeting.placeholder.informal', 'Marcus')</code>.</p><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Pluralization</h3><a id="user-content-pluralization" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: Pluralization" href="#pluralization"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">Object notation also supports pluralization. When making use of it, the "one" and "other" entries are used implicitly for an object in the translation document. For example, consider the following document:</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-json notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="{  "pets": {    "cat": {      "one": "Katze",      "other": "Katzen"    }  }}"><pre>{  <span class="pl-ent">"pets"</span>: {    <span class="pl-ent">"cat"</span>: {      <span class="pl-ent">"one"</span>: <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>Katze<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>,      <span class="pl-ent">"other"</span>: <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>Katzen<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>    }  }}</pre></div><p dir="auto">When accessing these, you would use <code>__n("pets.cat", "pets.cat", 3)</code> to tell i18n to use both the singular and plural form of the "cat" entry. Naturally, you could also access these members explicitly with <code>__("pets.cat.one")</code> and <code>__("pets.cat.other")</code>.</p><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Defaults</h3><a id="user-content-defaults" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: Defaults" href="#defaults"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">When starting a project from scratch, your translation documents will probably be empty. i18n takes care of filling your translation documents for you. Whenever you use an unknown object, it is added to the translation documents.</p><p dir="auto">By default, when using object notation, the provided string literal will be inserted and returned as the default string. As an example, this is what the "greeting" object shown earlier would look like by default:</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-json notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="{  "greeting": {    "formal": "greeting.formal",    "informal": "greeting.informal"  }}"><pre>{  <span class="pl-ent">"greeting"</span>: {    <span class="pl-ent">"formal"</span>: <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>greeting.formal<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>,    <span class="pl-ent">"informal"</span>: <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>greeting.informal<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>  }}</pre></div><p dir="auto">In case you would prefer to have a default string automatically inserted and returned, you can provide that default string by appending it to your object literal, delimited by a <code>:</code>. For example:</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-js notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="__('greeting.formal:Hello')__('greeting.placeholder.informal:Hi %s')"><pre><span class="pl-c1">__</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-s">'greeting.formal:Hello'</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span><span class="pl-c1">__</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-s">'greeting.placeholder.informal:Hi %s'</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span></pre></div><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h2 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Storage</h2><a id="user-content-storage" class="anchor-element" class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h2 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Logging & Debugging</h2><a id="user-content-logging--debugging" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: href="https://github.com/visionmedia/debug">debug</a> module. To let i18n output anything run your app with <code>DEBUG</code> env set like so:</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-shell notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="$ DEBUG=i18n:* node app.js"><pre>$ DEBUG=i18n:<span class="pl-k">*</span> node app.js</pre></div><p dir="auto">i18n exposes three log-levels:</p><ul dir="auto"><li>i18n:debug</li><li>i18n:warn</li><li>i18n:error</li></ul><p dir="auto">if you only want to get errors and warnings reported start your node server like so:</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-shell notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="$ DEBUG=i18n:warn,i18n:error node app.js"><pre>$ DEBUG=i18n:warn,i18n:error node app.js</pre></div><p dir="auto">Combine those settings with you existing application if any of you other modules or libs also uses <strong>debug</strong></p><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Using custom logger</h3><a id="user-content-using-custom-logger" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: Using custom logger" href="#using-custom-logger"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">You can configure i18n to use a custom logger. For example attach some simple <code>console</code>-logging:</p><div class="highlight highlight-source-js notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="i18n.configure({  // setting of log level DEBUG - default to require('debug')('i18n:debug')  logDebugFn: function (msg) {    console.log('debug', msg)  },  // setting of log level WARN - default to require('debug')('i18n:warn')  logWarnFn: function (msg) {    console.log('warn', msg)  },  // setting of log level ERROR - default to require('debug')('i18n:error')  logErrorFn: function (msg) {    console.log('error', msg)  }})"><pre><span class="pl-s1">i18n</span><span class="pl-kos">.</span><span class="pl-en">configure</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-kos">{</span>  <span class="pl-c">// setting of log level DEBUG - default to require('debug')('i18n:debug')</span>  <span class="pl-en">logDebugFn</span>: <span class="pl-k">function</span> <span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-s1">msg</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span> <span class="pl-kos">{</span>    <span class="pl-smi">console</span><span class="pl-kos">.</span><span class="pl-en">log</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-s">'debug'</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-s1">msg</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span>  <span class="pl-kos">}</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span>  <span class="pl-c">// setting of log level WARN - default to require('debug')('i18n:warn')</span>  <span class="pl-en">logWarnFn</span>: <span class="pl-k">function</span> <span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-s1">msg</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span> <span class="pl-kos">{</span>    <span class="pl-smi">console</span><span class="pl-kos">.</span><span class="pl-en">log</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-s">'warn'</span><span
